title: Construct Natural-Language Lists with Internationalization
text: () creates “”-separated lists vectors. Oxford comma less common varieties English, happens change R language British English? languages?
code: names <- c("John", "Paul", "George", "Ringo") and(names) #> [1] "John, Paul, George, and Ringo" Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "en_GB") and(names) #> [1] "John, Paul, George and Ringo" Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "es") and(names) #> [1] "John, Paul, George y Ringo" Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "eu") and(names) #> [1] "John, Paul, George eta Ringo" Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "ko") and(names) #> [1] "John, Paul, George 및 Ringo"

text: Everything () can () can better. Just use () create -separated lists contextual awareness.
code: outcomes <- c("win", "lose", "draw") Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "en_US") or(outcomes) #> [1] "win, lose, or draw" Sys.setenv(LANGUAGE = "ja") or(outcomes) #> [1] "win、lose、またはdraw"

title: Construct Natural-Language Lists with Internationalization
text: Don’t want language string depend user’s environment variables? can explicitly set language using language argument.
code: and(names, language = "en_US") #> [1] "John, Paul, George, and Ringo" and(names, language = "en_GB") #> [1] "John, Paul, George and Ringo" and(names, language = "es") #> [1] "John, Paul, George y Ringo" and(names, language = "fr") #> [1] "John, Paul, George et Ringo"

title: Change the language of the current R environment — set_language
Change the language of the current R environment — set_language
text: language language code. Codes two three lowercase letters representing language, optionally followed underscore two uppercase letters representing territory. example, "es" represents Spanish "en_US" represents American English. territory specified specific translation territory, translations fall back general language. example, specific translations Canadian French, "fr_CA" fall back "fr". language specified translation language, translations generally fall back English. language empty string NULL, LANGUAGE environment variable unset.

title: Change the language of the current R environment — set_language
text: Returns pre-existing value LANGUAGE environment variable

title: Change the language of the current R environment — set_language
code: # Change language to Korean set_language("ko")  # Change language to Mexican Spanish, which may fall back to "es" set_language("es_MX")  # Temporarily set the language to Cantonese old_language <- set_language("yue") set_language(old_language)  # Change to an invalid language, which generally falls back to English set_language("zxx")  # Unset the language environment variable set_language(NULL)
